title: Universality of Three-Place Identity
description: Tom Etter's Universality Theorem: three-place relative identity is foundationally adequate for all of mathematics, establishing mutual interpretability with ZF set theory.

meta.author: Tom Etter (formalized in Lean 4)
originalContributions: First Lean 4 formalization of Etter's three-place identity theory
Machine-verified round-trip theorem between identity and membership
Formal proof that Foundation axiom is essential for mutual interpretability
Demonstrates perspectival ontology in formal foundations

overview.historicalContext:
The question 'what is the primitive concept of mathematics?' has occupied logicians since Frege. The standard answer—set membership—proved technically successful but philosophically troubling. Benacerraf's problem (why is 2 = {empty, {empty}} rather than {{empty}}?) suggests sets don't capture mathematical essence.

Tom Etter, working at the Boundary Institute, proposed a radical alternative: three-place relative identity Id(x,y,z)—read 'x regards y as identical to z'—is the true primitive, with existence derived as distinguishability from non-existence. This formalizes Gian-Carlo Rota's slogan 'Identity precedes existence.'
overview.problemStatement:
**Theorem (Etter Universality):** Three-place relative identity is foundationally adequate for all of mathematics.

More precisely: There exist definitional bridges D1 and D2 such that:
1. Any membership relation induces a valid identity structure (D2 preserves axioms)
2. Starting from ZF membership with Foundation, the round-trip through identity recovers the original membership
3. Therefore ZF axioms on derived membership are consistent with identity axioms
overview.proofStrategy:
The proof constructs two bridges:

**D1 (Membership from Identity):** y in' x := not Id(x, y, x)
- 'y exists for x when x distinguishes y from itself'

**D2 (Identity from Membership):** Id_mem(x,y,z) := (y in x and z in x) or (not y in x and not z in x)
- 'x regards y,z as same when they have equal membership status'

We verify D2 preserves the identity axioms by case analysis. The round-trip theorem uses the Foundation axiom (not x in x) critically: it ensures x serves as a genuine 'null element.' Universality follows: any ZF model induces an identity structure whose derived membership matches the original.
keyInsights: Three-place identity Id(x,y,z) generalizes binary identity by making the 'viewpoint' x a variable—different perspectives may identify different things
Existence is derived, not primitive: to exist for x means to be distinguishable from the undifferentiated background (x itself)
The Foundation axiom (no set contains itself) is essential—it ensures the 'null viewpoint' x is genuinely empty
This formalizes Gian-Carlo Rota's slogan 'Identity precedes existence' with mathematical precision
The construction parallels Dedekind's derivation of reals from rationals—sets don't disappear, but their foundational status changes
Connects to Quine's insight: Id_mem(x,y,z) iff (y in x iff z in x)—identity as indistinguishability relative to a predicate

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Overview of the proof and its significance: formalizing Etter's claim that three-place identity is foundationally universal.

sections.title: The Relative Identity Structure
sections.summary: Definition of RelativeIdentity: a three-place predicate where each fixed viewpoint induces an equivalence relation.

sections.title: Bridge D1: Membership from Identity
sections.summary: First bridge: y exists for x when x distinguishes y from itself. Formalizes 'existence as distinguishability.'

sections.title: Bridge D2: Identity from Membership
sections.summary: Second bridge: x regards y,z as identical when they have the same membership status. Connects to Quine's role identities.

sections.title: D2 Preserves Identity Structure
sections.summary: Proof that any membership relation induces a valid relative identity structure via D2.

sections.title: The Foundation Axiom
sections.summary: The ZF Foundation axiom: no set contains itself. Essential for the round-trip theorem.

sections.title: The Round-Trip Theorem
sections.summary: The key result: mem -> Id_mem -> mem' = mem. Identity and membership are mutually interpretable.

sections.title: The Universality Theorem
sections.summary: The main theorem: identity theory can express all of mathematics via the ZF-derived membership.

sections.title: Philosophical Consequences
sections.summary: Discussion of implications: identity precedes existence, relativity of ontology, connection to Quine.

sections.title: Examples and Verification
sections.summary: Concrete examples: trivial identity, discrete identity, and verification with natural numbers.

conclusion.summary: We have formalized Etter's Universality Theorem: three-place relative identity suffices as a foundation for mathematics. The two bridges D1 and D2 establish mutual interpretability with ZF set theory, with the round-trip recovering original membership when Foundation holds. This is not merely a technical curiosity—it demonstrates that perspectival indistinguishability may be more fundamental than absolute existence.
conclusion.implications: The result has deep philosophical consequences. It makes rigorous Rota's 'identity precedes existence': we don't first posit objects then ask if they're identical—rather, identity structures induce what exists. This resonates with constructive mathematics (existence requires construction), category theory (objects defined up to isomorphism), and quantum mechanics (observer-dependence of outcomes). The loss of absolute identity may resolve puzzles about identity through time and across possible worlds.
openQuestions: What happens with non-well-founded set theories (Aczel's AFA)? The round-trip uses Foundation essentially.
Etter's 'Stereo Equality Theorem' claims two separate equality predicates suffice—can this be formalized?
Is there a categorical semantics? Three-place identity suggests indexed equivalence relations, connecting to fibered categories.
Can the quantum logic connection Etter hints at yield new foundations for quantum mechanics?
How does this relate to homotopy type theory's treatment of identity types and univalence?

alternativeInterpretation.title: The Meta-Level Objection: What Does This Really Prove?
alternativeInterpretation.summary: A careful reader might object: this formalization works *within* Lean's type theory, using its built-in logical connectives (Prop, Not, And, Or, forall). But Etter's claim is that three-place identity can serve as a *foundation* for mathematics. Can we prove a foundation is adequate by working inside another foundation?
alternativeInterpretation.perspective:
**What This Proof Establishes**: The algebraic content of Etter's bridges—that there exist definitional translations between identity and membership structures, and that the round-trip preserves membership when Foundation holds.

**What a Full Foundational Proof Would Require**: To genuinely establish that identity theory is foundationally adequate, one would need to:

1. Define identity theory as a formal system (syntax, axioms, inference rules)
2. Build models of this system
3. Show ZF can be *interpreted within* identity theory—not just that there's a correspondence when both are formalized in a common meta-theory

This is analogous to Gödel's distinction between object language and meta-language. When Gödel proved incompleteness, he carefully encoded formulas as numbers and distinguished claims *about* the system from claims *within* it. A rigorous foundational proof of Etter's universality would require similar care about levels of abstraction.
alternativeInterpretation.godelAnalogy:
The situation parallels Gödel's famous proof:

- **Object level**: The formal system being studied (Peano Arithmetic for Gödel, identity theory for Etter)
- **Meta level**: The language used to reason about the system (informal mathematics for Gödel, Lean's type theory here)
- **The challenge**: Claims about foundational adequacy must be made at the right level

Our Lean proof shows that *within Lean's type theory*, there's a beautiful correspondence between identity and membership structures. It doesn't show that identity theory, as a standalone formal system, can encode all of mathematics without borrowing logical infrastructure from elsewhere.
alternativeInterpretation.whatWeActuallyProve:
The formalization rigorously establishes:

1. **D1 and D2 are well-defined bridges** between any identity structure and membership relations
2. **D2 preserves the identity axioms**—any membership relation induces a valid RelativeIdentity
3. **The round-trip theorem** holds when Foundation is satisfied
4. **Foundation is essential**—the proof genuinely requires ¬(x ∈ x)

These are substantive mathematical results. The philosophical interpretation—whether this makes identity 'more fundamental' than membership—remains a separate question that formal proofs cannot fully settle.
alternativeInterpretation.alternativeApproach:
A more rigorous approach would build identity theory as an explicit object language within Lean:

```lean
-- Syntax of identity theory formulas
inductive ITFormula : Type where
  | id : Term → Term → Term → ITFormula  -- Id(x,y,z)
  | conj : ITFormula → ITFormula → ITFormula
  | neg : ITFormula → ITFormula
  -- etc.

-- Semantics: interpretations in a structure
structure ITModel where
  carrier : Type
  interp : ITFormula → Prop
  -- satisfaction conditions...

-- Then prove: ZF axioms are satisfiable in ITModel
```

This would genuinely show identity theory's foundational power, rather than demonstrating a correspondence within a shared meta-theory.
alternativeInterpretation.historicalContext:
The distinction between object and meta-level is central to mathematical logic since Hilbert and Gödel. Alternative foundational proposals—from Russell's type theory to Martin-Löf's intuitionistic type theory to Voevodsky's univalent foundations—all face the same challenge: how do you prove a foundation is adequate without assuming some prior foundation?

The standard resolution is *relative consistency*: we show Foundation A can interpret Foundation B, meaning B is consistent if A is. Our proof establishes something like this: identity theory can interpret ZF membership (under Foundation). But since we work inside Lean, we're really showing Lean's type theory can express both.
alternativeInterpretation.leanFoundations:
Lean itself is built on the Calculus of Inductive Constructions—a dependent type theory that already has identity (Eq), propositions (Prop), and logical connectives as primitives. When we 'define' three-place identity in Lean, we're defining a structure using Lean's existing logical machinery, not building identity theory from scratch.

This isn't a criticism of the formalization—it's simply clarity about what's being proven. The algebraic elegance of Etter's bridges is real and verified. The philosophical claim about foundational priority requires additional argument beyond what any formalization in Lean can provide.
alternativeInterpretation.seeAlso: For an alternative Lean 4 formalization that addresses some of these concerns with a more modular approach, see [Jim Bowery's RelativeIdentity project](https://github.com/jabowery/RelativeIdentity).
